Get examples going of JavaScript observables
body:
- what are the differences between observables and promises
	- a promise resolves to a single value asynchronously, an observable resolves to (or emits) multiple values asynchronously (over time)
	- concrete examples: 
		- promise = response from an Ajax call
		- observable = a click event
	- observables are a representation for a possibly infinite amount of values
	- promises are designed to represent AJAX calls
		- observables are designed to represent anything: events, data from databases, data from ajax calls
	- a promise is often a good choice when you want to fetch a single chunk of data
	- if your component gets data with only one request it's a good choice to use Promise but if it has a chain of request-cancel-new request you should use observable
	- observables provide many values, promises provide one
	- ES6 added built-in support for promises to JavaScript
		- observables were 2017 ECMA proposal that wasn't adopted
	- to use promises, use the RxJA library: http://reactivex.io
		- )) work through this [Functional Programming in Javascript Tutorial](http://reactivex.io/learnrx)

title: Learn SED Basics
body:
- basics
	- get files 
		- `cp /usr/share/common-licenses/BSD .`
		- `cp /usr/share/common-licenses/GPL-3 .`
	- get first five lines
		- `sed -n '1,5p' BSD`
	- print every other line
		- `sed -n '1~2p' BSD`
	- delete every other line
		- `sed '1~2d' BSD`
	- delete every other line and save it to a new file
		- `sed '1~2d' BSD > everyother.txt`
	- delete every other line and save changes in that file
		- `sed -i '1~2d' everyother.txt`
	- make backup first, then delete every other line and save changes in that file
		- `sed -i.bak '1~2d' everyother.txt`
	- replace all "a" with "x" (/g is for all matches in line, not just the first)
		- `sed 's/a/x/g' BSD`
	- replace 'and' with '***' and print out the lines in which there were changes
		- `sed -n 's/and/***/gp' BSD`
	- same thing as case-insensitive
		- `sed -n 's/and/***/gpi' BSD`
	- use regular expressions, e.g. change "and" only at the beginning of a line
		- `sed -n 's/^and/***/gpi' BSD`
	- put brackets around "and"
		- `sed -n 's/and/[&]/gpi' BSD`
	- if you have text with slashes, use another character as the divider
		- `echo "files/version001/index.html" | sed 's_files/version_files/BLANK_'`
- pipe output of commands to SED
	- replace all digits with stars in a directory listing (you can't use \d)
		- `ls -al | sed 's/[[:digit:]]/*/g'`
	- erase the time from a directory listing
		- `ls -al | sed 's/[[:digit:]][[:digit:]]:[[:digit:]][[:digit:]]\s//g'`
	- don't list directories
		- `ls -al | sed '/^d/d'`
- sed scripts
	- create file `dirparse.sed`:
		---------------------------
		/^d/d
		s/[[:digit:]][[:digit:]]:[[:digit:]][[:digit:]]\s//g
		---------------------------
	- then run: `ls -al | sed -f dirparse.sed`
- create a command with script
	- `alias ld="ls -al | sed -f ~/work/sed/dirparse.sed`
- %% these are sed basics

	- so I made some change so I could use Virtual Box

	- it asks me this:##dockaskme
	- here's a [good explanation from 2018](https://medium.com/@javier.ramos1/docker-windows-vs-linux-1bb26d8090b3)
		- With Windows 10 Pro, Microsoft introduced the Hyper-V, which is a super fast virtualization tool, Docker for Windows was launched for Windows 10 Pro, to run containers much faster and easier, but you need Windows 10 Pro, Home will not work.
		- When Windows Server 2016 was launched, it was re architecture to support a kind of isolated process, so it can run Docker natively without Hyper-V or any virtualization. As of today, Windows Server 2016 is the only windows system that support native containers, however, the most basic image is 5GB big which is not very efficient.
		- Windows server runs Windows containers natively and uses Hyper-V for Linux.
		- Also, when you run Windows Containers you cannot run Linux ones, so you have to choose one or the other. Since 99% of the images are Linux base, and .NET can run on Linux, Windows containers are not that useful.
		- Use Linux for Containers, it is always the best option.
		- Windows 10 Pro with Hyper-V is a good option to run in your PC/Laptop, but Linux will always be better
		- There is no support for Windows containers in most cloud providers or Kubernetes.
			- Apparently with Windows 2019 this is no longer true.
	- [article on Docker](https://forums.docker.com/t/hyper-v-or-native-windows-containers/44631)
		- No, on Windows 10 only Hyper-V isolation is available. The Windows 10 kernel configuration is a little different from the Windows Server kernel configuration, so Hyper-V isolation is required.
- ok, since Linux is obviously the default and since I can change it later, I left this book unclicked and **will use Linux containers**

title: 100 MySQL Questions and Answers
body:
- sources
	- https://career.guru99.com/top-50-mysql-interview-questions-answers/
- **1. Differentiate between FLOAT and DOUBLE? **
	- Doubles are just like floats, except for the fact that they are twice as large. This allows for a greater accuracy.
- **2. Differentiate CHAR_LENGTH and LENGTH**
	- CHAR_LENGTH is character count whereas the LENGTH is byte count. The numbers are same for Latin characters but they are different for Unicode and other encodings.
- **3. What are the different kinds of tables?**
	- **INNO DB** - SELECT wird schneller ausgeführt, as of MySQL 5.5 the default storage engine, InnoDB has row-level locking. MyISAM only has full table-level locking
	- **MyISAM** - Häufiger genutzt und gängigster Standard 
	- **Heap** - refers to a table created with the MEMORY storage engine, the MEMORY storage engine does not persist any data to disk; it holds data in RAM
	- **Merge** - when you create a MERGE table, MySQL creates a . MRG file on disk that contains the names of the underlying MyISAM tables that should be used as one.
	- **ISAM** - The original storage engine in MySQL was the ISAM engine, the only storage engine available until MySQL 3.23, Due to the deprecated status of ISAM, and because MyISAM is an improvement over ISAM, you are advised to convert any remaining ISAM tables to MySAM as soon as possible.

	- both built on top of IP protocol
	- both send packets over the Internet
	- packets are sent to IP addresses, travel over routers
	- User Datagram Protocol
	- Transmission Control Protocol

title: Install and learn basic querying in MongoDB
body:
- install
	- download https://www.mongodb.com/try/download/community
	- execute 
	- be sure "Install MongoDB Compass" is checked
- change environment path
	- copy e.g. `C:\Program Files\MongoDB\Server\4.4\bin`
	- go to environment variables
	- system variables, path, new, add path
- download MongoDB tools
	- *"As of MongoDB 4.4, the server tools are also packaged separately and have different versioning."*
	- [Download MongoDB Tools](https://www.mongodb.com/try/download/database-tools?tck=docs_databasetools)
	- unzip and copy all files:##mongotoolsdownload
	- open Windows Explorer as administrator (`C:\Windows\explorer.exe`) right-click and "Run as Administrator"
		- go to `C:\Program Files\MongoDB\Server\4.4\bin`
		- paste
- look at databases
	- `cd C:\projects\mongobasic`
	- `mongo`
	- `show dbs;`
	- `exit`
- import data from JSON file
	- `mongoimport --db howtos --file items_howtos.json --jsonArray`
	- `mongo`
	- `show dbs;`
	- `use howtos;`
	- `show collections;`
	- `exit`
- create documents
	- `flashcard = { "front" : "house", "back" : "Haus" }`
	- `db.flashcards.insertOne(flashcard)`
	- `show dbs`
	- `use test`
	- `show collections`
- query documents
	- `db.flashcards.find()`
	- `db.items_flashcards.find({"category":"vim"})`
	- `db.items_flashcards.find({"category":"vim"}, {"front":1})`
	- `db.getCollection('items_flashcards').find({front: {$regex: /local/i}}, {front: 1, back: 1}).pretty()`
	- `db.items_howtos.find({}, {title: 1}).limit(2)`
	- `db.items_howtos.find().count()`
- sort
	- `db.items_howtos.find({}, {title: 1}).limit(7).sort({title: 1})`
	- `db.items_howtos.find({}, {title: 1}).limit(7).sort({title: -1})`
	- note it seems to do the sort first, then the limit, with either order
	- `db.items_howtos.find({}, {title: 1}).sort({title: 1}).limit(7)`
	- `db.items_howtos.find({}, {title: 1}).sort({title: -1}).limit(7)`
- various commands
	- `db.getName()`
- download [Robo 3T](https://robomongo.org/download)

title: Install Moodle 3.10.1 locally on Ubuntu and get H5P quizzes to work
body:
- requires MySQL 5.7.0
- I have an Ubuntu 20.04.1 LTS running in a Hyper-V virtual machine
	- trying to connect via ssh
	- `ifconfig` shows 172.17.88.89
	- from windows `ping 172.17.88.89`
		- gets a response
	- setup ssh on Ubuntu
		- `sudo vim /etc/ssh/ssh_config`
			- search for `22`
			- remove the `#`
		- `sudo apt-get install openssh-server openssh-client`
	- `ssh test@172.17.88.89`
- working with this tutorial [install Moodle on Ubuntu](https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/Step-by-step_Installation_Guide_for_Ubuntu)
	- install Apache and MySQL
		- `sudo apt install apache2 mysql-client mysql-server php libapache2-mod-php`
		- `sudo mysql_secure_installation`, local test password: `rootroot`
	- install supporting software for Moodle
		- `sudo apt install graphviz aspell ghostscript clamav php7.4-pspell php7.4-curl php7.4-gd php7.4-intl php7.4-mysql php7.4-xml php7.4-xmlrpc php7.4-ldap php7.4-zip php7.4-soap php7.4-mbstring`
	- restart Apache so that the modules are loaded correctly 
		- `sudo service apache2 restart`
	- install Git in order to install Moodle
		- `sudo apt install git`
	- install Moodle
		- `cd /opt` (option packages, was empty)
		- `sudo git clone git://git.moodle.org/moodle.git`
			- error
				---------------------------
				fatal: the remote end hung up unexpectedly109.24 MiB | 48.00 KiB/s 
				fatal: early EOF
				fatal: index-pack failed
				---------------------------
			- and no `moodle` direction
			- ran it again, no error this time:
				------------------------------
				Cloning into 'moodle'...
				remote: Counting objects: 1202654, done.
				remote: Total 1202654 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
				Receiving objects: 100% (1202654/1202654), 402.80 MiB | 3.46 MiB/s, done.
				Resolving deltas: 100% (897170/897170), done.
				Updating files: 100% (21508/21508), done.
				------------------------------
		- `cd moodle`
		- `sudo git branch -a` to see all branches
		- get version 3.9
			- `sudo git branch --track MOODLE_39_STABLE origin/MOODLE_39_STABLE`
			- `sudo git checkout MOODLE_39_STABLE`
		- copy local repository to /var/www/html/
			- `sudo cp -R /opt/moodle /var/www/html/` 
				- (/var = files that vary often but are not temporary, e.g. logs)
			- `sudo mkdir /var/moodledata`
			- `sudo chown -R www-data /var/moodledata`
			- `sudo chmod -R 777 /var/moodledata`
			- `sudo chmod -R 0755 /var/www/html/moodle`
		- install MySQL
			- change config file
				- **SKIP TO 001 BELOW**
				- `sudo vim /etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf`
				- below `[mysqld]` add:
					---------------------------
					default_storage_engine = innodb
					innodb_file_per_table = 1
					innodb_file_format = Barracuda
					---------------------------
			- start MySQL and login
				- **001: JUST RESTART**
				- `sudo service mysql restart`
					------------------------------
					Job for mysql.service failed because the control process exited with error code.
					See "systemctl status mysql.service" and "journalctl -xe" for details.
					------------------------------
				- `sudo mysql -u root -p`
					- local temp password: `rootroot`
				- `CREATE DATABASE moodle DEFAULT CHARACTER SET utf8mb4 COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci;`
				- `create user 'admin'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'Admin$123';` ("Admin$123" is local temp password)		
				- `GRANT SELECT,INSERT,UPDATE,DELETE,CREATE,CREATE TEMPORARY TABLES,DROP,INDEX,ALTER ON moodle.* TO 'admin'@'localhost';`
				- `quit;`
				- `mysqld --version`
					- */usr/sbin/mysqld  Ver 8.0.23-0ubuntu0.20.04.1 for Linux on x86_64 ((Ubuntu))*
			- complete setup
				- `sudo chmod -R 777 /var/www/html/moodle`
				- (later revert like this: `sudo chmod -R 0755 /var/www/html/moodle`)
		- setup Moodle in browser
			- get IP-address with `ifconfig`
			- browser: `http://172.17.88.89/moodle`
			- data directory: `/var/moodledata`
			- database
				- Type: *mysqli*
				- Database host: *localhost*
				- Database name: *moodle*
				- Database user: *admin*
				- Database password: *Admin$123*
				- Tables Prefix: *mdl_*
			- **does checks for about 10 minutes, just wait**
			- set up H5P
	- works well in Ubuntu:##theubuntumoodworks
- The **[installation on Debian](https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/Installing_Moodle_on_Debian_based_distributions)** seems similar

title: Setup Docker on Ubuntu, start containers and make a container
body:
- these are notes from a workshop on Docker in which we successfully installed Docker on Ubuntu, started a few containers and created a Hello-World container
- I copied all the commands we used here the best I could
- execute this script
	--------------------------------
	#!/usr/bin/env bash
	set -e

	# Author: Thomas Hofmann<thomas@savoy-truffle.de>
​
	# according to
	# https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/linux/ubuntu/#os-requirements

	export lang=en_US.UTF-8

	KEY_ID='0EBFCD88'
	KEY_SOURCE='https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu/gpg'
	FINGERPRINT="9DC8 5822 9FC7 DD38 854A E2D8 8D81 803C 0EBF CD88"

	#parent of linuxmint # for ubuntu: UBUNTU_PARENT=$(lsb_release -cs)
	. /etc/os-release
	UBUNTU_PARENT=$UBUNTU_CODENAME

	function usage() {
		echo "usage: $0"
	}

	function install_prerequisites() {
		sudo apt-get install -y \
			apt-transport-https \
			ca-certificates \
			curl \
			libcurl4 \
			software-properties-common \
			lsb-release
	}

	function add_repository() {
		sudo bash -c "echo \"deb [arch=amd64] https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu \
			$UBUNTU_CODENAME \
			stable\" \
			> /etc/apt/sources.list.d/docker.list"
	}

	function install_key() {
		curl -fsSL $KEY_SOURCE \
		| sudo apt-key add -
	}

	function _installed_fingerprint() {
		key_id=$1
		apt-key fingerprint $key_id \
		| head -2 \
		| tail -1 \
		| sed 's/^\s*//' \
		| sed 's/  / /' # fixing the double-space-character of apt-key output
	}

	function _isKeyValid() {
		expected=$FINGERPRINT
		installed=`_installed_fingerprint $KEY_ID`

		if [ "$expected" == "$installed" ];
		then
			echo 1
		else
			echo 0
		fi
	}

	function install_docker() {
		sudo apt-get update
		sudo apt-get install -y docker-ce
	}

	# *** "MAIN" ***********************************************

	install_prerequisites

	installed_fingerprint=`_installed_fingerprint $KEY_ID`;
	if [ -z "$installed_fingerprint" ]; then
		echo "install key"
		install_key
	fi

	if [ `_isKeyValid` -eq 1 ]; then
		echo "add repository"
		add_repository
	else
		echo "ERROR: could not add repository"
		echo "       comparison of keys's fingerprints failed"
		installed_fingerprint=`_installed_fingerprint $KEY_ID`;
		echo "installed: $installed_fingerprint"
		echo "expected:  $FINGERPRINT"
		echo "manually perform: apt-key fingerprint $KEY_ID"
		exit 1
	fi

	install_docker\
&& echo '******************************************'\
&& echo '* Note:                                  *'\
&& echo '*   add users to usergroup "docker",     *'\
&& echo '*   e. g. with:                          *'\
&& echo '*   $> sudo addgroup USER docker         *'\
&& echo '*   then logout and login again          *'\
&& echo '******************************************'\
&& echo ''
	--------------------------------
- `sudo addgroup USER docker`
	- logout and login
- various commands to get Docker setup and working
	- `sudo ./install.docker-ce.sh`
	- `chmod u+x install.docker-ce.sh`
	- `sudo addgroup your_user_name docker`
	- `docker version`
	- `docker run -it --rm debian:stable-slim bash`
	- `docker image ls`
	- https://hub.docker.com
	- `docker run debian:stable-slim echo "hello world"`
	- `docker run --rm -d debian:stable-slim sleep 10`
	- `docker ps`

	- `code Dockerfile`
		---------------------------
		FROM debian:stable-slim
		CMD echo "hello world"
		---------------------------

	- `docker image ls | grep hello_world`
	- `docker run hello_world`

title: Set up Laravel 8 site on Ubuntu
body:
- install  XAMPP
	- [XAMPP on Ubuntu](https://onespace.netlify.app/forays?id=198)
- install composer
	- `sudo apt update`
	- `sudo apt install php-cli unzip`
	- `cd ~`
	- `curl -sS https://getcomposer.org/installer -o /tmp/composer-setup.php`
		- `-sS` = *be quiet by show errors*
		- `-o` = output file
	- `sudo php /tmp/composer-setup.php --install-dir=/usr/local/bin --filename=composer`
	- test with: `composer`
- install Laravel site
	- go to your `webs` directory
	- `composer create-project --prefer-dist laravel/laravel site-laravel-002 --ignore-platform-req=ext-dom --ignore-platform-req=ext-dom --ignore-platform-req=ext-xml --ignore-platform-req=ext-xmlwriter`
- start Laravel site
	- `cd site-laravel-002`
	- `php artisan start`

title: Fix the vulnerability issues displayed when creating a site with create-react-app
body:
-  in January 2022 I was still using create-react-app starter code that I created from an August 2021 build of create-react-app and noticed that it now gets 22 vulnerabilities, one of them being critical##thereactbuls
	- so I typed `npm audit` and got more information on the vulnerabilities:##reactgetmoreinforamiotnvuls
	- by googling the one critical vulnerability *prototype pollution in immer*, I found many other people concerned about this and trying to fix it
	- I found [this fix](https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/pull/10412) from February 2021 which advises to **update immer to 8.0.1 to address vulnerability**
	- I then saw that that I could apparently fix all the vulnerabilities automatically by typing *npm audit fix*, but this didn't fix any of them##reactnotfixok
	- I took further advice listed to type *npm audit fix --force*, notice it says that one package update *involved breaking changes* which sounds ominous ##usedfixforceonreact
	- although it said that 3 vulnerabilities could not be updated, typing `npm audit` again showed that there are now only two##nowonlytworeact
	- only having 2 vulnerabilities instead of 22, and no critical vulnerabilities, gives one a better feeling of security, particularly if one is working on a production project, but the message that there are now *breaking changes* in this React app is unsettling. 
		- .. to get experience with this, I will now use this build with these fixes and to see if I run into any problems because of these apparent "breaking changes"
- out of curiosity, I installed a fresh create-react-app with `npx create-react-app cra2022-01-23` to see if any of these vulnerabilities had been corrected since my August 2021 package.json
	- it seems that there are only two vulnerabilities after a fresh install:##seemsonlytworeact
	- and comparing the package.json files from both builds, it seems there was a major update to react-scripts in the last half year:##403to500
- I wanted to update my blankcra site so that it doesn't have the 22 vulnerabilities so simply updated the version of react-scripts in my package.json file:
	- from: `"react-scripts": "4.0.3",`
	- to: `"react-scripts": "^5.0.0",`
	- this seems to work well:##seemstoreactworkwell
- through researching this, I came upon this critical article on how npm audit works: [npm audit: Broken by Design](https://overreacted.io/npm-audit-broken-by-design)

Upgrading an out-of-date React site to resolve vulnerabilities
body:
- my Datapod site in April 2022 is still running on **create-react-app** files that I installed in summer 2021
- when I do an `npm i` I get the following warnings:##crasiteoldwarn
- I see **react-scripts** has a newer major version##reactsssup
- and **React** is now on version 18##reactison18
- so changed both to the newest version in **package.json**:##chnagedbothrea
- deleted **package-lock.json**
- deleted **node_modules** (`rm -rf node_modules`)
- ran `npm i`
- less warnings now##newbetterksjdf
- ran `npm audit fix`
	- but that didn't fix any of them##didntwokss
- ran `npm audit`
	- the 5 high vulnerabilities are all from the `sqlite3` package, which I use to transfer data from my old Node/Express/sqlite site to my current React/JSON site##didntwokss
	- and there seems to be no higher version at the moment:##nohighverskk
	- apparently I'm not the only one concerned about this:##seemstobecomm
	- there is no mention of these on the [sqlite3 npm page](https://www.npmjs.com/package/sqlite3)
	- on [SQLite's Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures](https://www.sqlite.org/cves.html), I find *Very few CVEs written about SQLite are real vulnerabilities in the sense that they do not give any new capabilities to an attacker.*
	- the data I have in my sqlite3 database is not sensitive so this is not an issue for me, and so these vulnerabilities have for me the status **will not fix**
- started the site with `npm start`
	- terminal says **webpack 5.72.0 compiled with 5 errors in 19710 ms**
	- received this page of errors:##pageoferrosks
		- **items.ts line 3**##
			- actually `fs` is loaded on line 2##actuline2
			- researching error, seems the [downloading to react-scripts 4](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/70591567/module-not-found-error-cant-resolve-fs-in-react) is a fix:##downladifrto4
			- the reason I have these references to `fs` is that I am using these files from the backend, which is Node, not create-react-app, but apparently Webpack can't make this distinction
		- see that this breaking change is given explicitly in the terminal##breakingchange
- ok, since I want both a backend and frontend in one project, and since I don't want to eject create-react-app, I am going to revert back to react-scripts 4.0.3
	- deleted `node_modules`
	- deleted `package-lock.json`
	- change `react-scripts` back to 4.0.3
	- `npm i`
	- so now I'm back to the critical vulnerabilities##backtocrrrr
	- but `npm start` shows the site to run fine now with
		- react 18.0.0
		- react-scripts 4.0.3
- since I want to keep both backend and frontend in this one project, I made a ticket to convert from **create-react-app** to **Vite**

- looking at these two services: - https://nodemailer.com - https://sendgrid.com - looking at https://nodemailer.com - make directory: et01-nodemailer-test - following Example here: https://nodemailer.com/about - too complicated - watching: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-nazR-yxaSk - they mentioned a w3schools example, switching to that - w3schools: https://www.w3schools.com/nodejs/nodejs_email.asp - it uses a gmail account and you have to send you password - so creating a dedicated gmail account - easy, finished in 10 minutes of clicking - got error: ---------------------------- Error: Invalid login: 535-5.7.8 Username and Password not accepted. Learn more at 535 5.7.8 https://support.google.com/mail/?p=BadCredentials eh2-20020a0564020f8200b0044402ac02f7sm3794642edb.67 - gsmtp ---------------------------- - reading this: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45478293/username-and-password-not-accepted-when-using-nodemailer - it seems: "On May 30 2022, you may lose access to apps that are using less secure sign-in technology" - following instructions under: "The solution is to enable 2-Step Verification and generate Application password, then you can use the generated password to send emails using nodemailer" - https://myaccount.google.com - Signing in to Google - 2-Step Verification - type smartphone number - SMS - typed in code from SMS, worked - App passwords - choose as app "other" - type in `nodemailer` - click [Generate] - copy the generated password and use it in as the password in your nodemailer code - after doing this I got: ------------------------------ Email sent: 250 2.0.0 OK 1660957634 r5-20020a056402018500b00445f8e0a86esm3807803edv.75 - gsmtp ------------------------------ - **success: mail arrived immediately** - testing with HTML - it doesn't work:##boldnowork - testing a hyperlink ----------------------------- text: 'testing, testing, this is a bold test\n\nPlease click here: https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos', ----------------------------- - works well##worksnicwnodlink - testing with HTML again based on: https://cheatcode.co/tutorials/how-to-send-email-with-nodemailer - trying this, note that **text** has been changed to **html** ------------------------------------ subject: 'Please confirm your registration', html: `

Please confirm your registration

Thank you for signing up with us!

Please click here to confirm your registration: https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos

`, ------------------------------------ - works great:##pleaseconfisdj - now trying to change the name the email recipient sees from email to text - trying ------------------------------------ from: 'Language Community Site <***********@gmail.com>', ------------------------------------ - looks good:##maillokksdgood - moving password to env file and switching to ES6 imports - worked - so this is the final nodemailer code that works to send emails for free: ---------------------------------------------- import { createTransport } from 'nodemailer'; import dotenv from 'dotenv'; dotenv.config(); var transporter = createTransport({ service: 'gmail', auth: { user: 'gmail-account-name', pass: process.env.PASSWORD, }, }); var mailOptions = { from: 'Language Community Site ', to: 'new-member@gmail.com', subject: 'Please confirm your registration', html: `

Please confirm your registration

Thank you for signing up with us!

Please click here to confirm your registration: https://edwardtanguay.netlify.app/howtos

`, }; transporter.sendMail(mailOptions, function (error, info) { if (error) { console.log(error); } else { console.log('Email sent: ' + info.response); } }); ---------------------------------------------- - %% nodemailer works well with Gmail

title: Get NodeMailer to work at Hetzner
body:
- problem 
	- my registration works on Hetzner, but I can't send mails##nodemailwokr
	- I wrote to Hetzner and got this response
		-------------------------------------
		Standardmäßig sind die Mailserver Ports 25 und 465 bei uns gesperrt. Nur Port 587 ist noch offen.
		>>https://docs.hetzner.com/cloud/servers/faq/#why-can-i-not-send-any-mails-from-my-server

		Sie finden es in Ihrer Projektübersicht im oberen Menü unter "Limits" oder unter folgendem Link:
		https://console.hetzner.cloud/limits

		Bei weiteren Fragen stehen wir Ihnen gerne zur Verfügung.		
		-------------------------------------
	- the [link](https://docs.hetzner.com/cloud/servers/faq/#why-can-i-not-send-any-mails-from-my-server) says this:##thelinksoksdfjiw
	- says to set secure to false for 587##the587
	- so here is my transporter:
		----------------------------------------
		const transporter = createTransport({
		  port: 587,
		  secure: false,
		  service: 'gmail',
		  tls: {
			rejectUnauthorized: false
		  },
		  auth: {
			user: process.env.MAILER_ACCOUNT_NAME,
			pass: process.env.MAILER_ACCOUNT_PASSWORD,
		  },
		});		
		----------------------------------------
	- `npm run build`
	- `npm start`
	- there is currently no firewall on so don't need to open up port 587
	- see information on [sending with Gmail](https://community.nodemailer.com/using-gmail):##thegooglaoud
- I [sent Hetzner a quick Anfrage](https://console.hetzner.cloud/limits) asking them to open the ports so I could send e-mails from my machines. You have to have paid at least one invoice. Mainly they just want to make sure you are not a spammer. Without a response, they apparently opened the appropriate ports so that NodeMailer can send mails from any of my machines.##emailhetznoworks

title: Get React site working that fetchs data and images from Contentful via REST and GraphQL
Create Gatsby 5 site with TypeScript, Contentful data combined with JSON file
body:
- resources - https://www.gatsbyjs.com/plugins/gatsby-source-contentful - **what we will do** - get a Gatsby website up and running, including: - add data to the `gatsby-config.js` file and retrieve it with GraphQL - contentful data and images combine with local JSON file and images all via GraphQL - install and use SASS - use MDX Markdown - add multiple pages with nav menu - use `` to create header and footer that shows on each page - use `` to display page title in tab header - images - use responsive images - use performance-optimized `` - deploy site at Vercel - make this a template site pinned on GitHub - there's apparently two ways to build a Gatsby site: - npm - `npm init gatsby` - it asks you many questions like Vite does - e.g. you can select Sass, TypeScript, Contentful - but site is quite reduced, simply a **src/pages/index.tsx** - Gatsby CLI - `gatsby new the-name-of-your-site` - asks no questions, builds a site that has a lot more boilerplate than the nbm install method - my strategy: - use the npm version to choose what you want, e.g. TypeScript, Sass, Contentful - but set up a Gatsby CLI site and look at the boilerplate, porting what you want over to your npm site - **NOTE:** Gatsby and Next.js are **React Frameworks** which use the **React library** to build a website - they use **React** just as e.g. **Vite** and **create-react-app** tools use the React library to build a website - however, **Gatsby** and **Next.js** bring a lot more infrastructure to the website which you need for larger projects - learning these two frameworks is different than learning **Angular** or **Vue.js** - instead of learning a **new framework** you are learning a **particular set of architecture design, code patterns and infrastructure tools added to React** - even if you end up not using these frameworks, learning them will give you good ideas and patterns how to organize and build React sites in general - one might express this in a metaphor of building a house:##metaphorhouse - **past Gatsby howtos and sites made** - HOWTO: Build a two-page website with Gatsby and host at Netlify - https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=478 - 2022-01-04 - code: [edwardtanguay/gatsby-edward-starter-site](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/gatsby-edward-starter-site) - site: [gatsby-edward-starter-site.netlify.app](https://gatsby-edward-starter-site.netlify.app) - site looks like this:#gif#gatsbyshowstarteredwww - 2022-05-31 - code: [edwardtanguay/gatsby-simple-site2](https://github.com/edwardtanguay/gatsby-simple-site2) - site: [gatsby-simple-site2.netlify.app](https://gatsby-simple-site2.netlify.app) - site looks like this:#gif#gatsby222ok - **==> STEP 1. Create simple Gatsby Site <==** - reading this:https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/quick-start - go to project folder - `npm init gatsby` - then you have to answer some questions##youhavetoans - ended with failure, it seems I have Node version **16.15.1** and need at least **18.0.0**:##thendfailsk - that's exactly the case:##1615 - and Node is currently at version 18##andnod18 - the easiest way to install a particular version of Node is with **nvm** - see if you have it installed first##seeifinstalv - if not then [install nvm on Linux with these instructions](https://heynode.com/tutorial/install-nodejs-locally-nvm) or [on Windows with these instructions](https://heynode.com/tutorial/install-nodejs-locally-nvm/) - after nvm is installed, use `nvm list` see which Node Versions you have locally downloaded ready to install:##seewhichin - if **version 18** is not listed, then see which versions are available to be installed with `nvm list available` - you want the latest LTS version:##youwantlatest - install the latest LTS version and use it with: `nvm install 18.12.1` - if you get an error, you may need to use `sudo` on Linux or open the Terminal as Adminstrator on Windows:##installthelatse - on Windows as administrator Node can be installed fine##installthelatseonwin - now with Node version 18+ install Gatsby again with `npm init gatsby` - it issues quite a number of warnings but installs with success##manywarnsbuton - enter directory: `cd et010-gatsby-contentful-etc` - start VSCode: `code .` - npm modules is already installed so no need to run `npm i` as with Vite - although you will find a **yarn.lock** file in root, Gatsby recommends using **npm** - *"Most tutorials and site development examples from the Gatsby docs use npm. To avoid confusion and possible conflicts with your dependencies, Gatsby recommends using npm for site development."* - https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/glossary/yarn - delete **yarn.lock** - start the Gatsby site with ----------------------------------- npm run develop ----------------------------------- - then click the link shown in the terminal##thelinksinsterm - **==> STEP 2. Examine and simplify the site <==** - note that **node_modules** is already built and **Git** is already installed - as the page suggests, edit `src/pages/index.tsx` to see the page update in real-time (as with Vite) - examine the code in the **index.tsx** page - inline styles as variables --------------------------------------- const descriptionStyle = { color: '#232129', fontSize: 14, marginTop: 10, marginBottom: 0, lineHeight: 1.25 };

{link.description}

--------------------------------------- - note how they extend the styles with spread operaters ------------------------------------- const links = [ { text: 'Tutorial', url: 'https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/tutorial/', description: "A great place to get started if you're new to web development. Designed to guide you through setting up your first Gatsby site.", color: '#E95800' }, ... ] const listItemStyles = { fontWeight: 300, fontSize: 24, maxWidth: 560, marginBottom: 30 };
  • ------------------------------------- - this is a reason why one should at least set up and look at other frameworks, to get new ideas of how one could structure one's own code even if one don't use the framework - example the TypeScript that Gatsby is using on this page ------------------------------------------ import type { HeadFC, PageProps } from 'gatsby'; const IndexPage: React.FC = () => { export const Head: HeadFC = () => Home Page; ------------------------------------------ - note you can change the text in the **** tag and it will change on the tab in your browser - this is important for SEO, i.e. that each page in your single-page-application has it's own title tag for e.g. search bots and social media link previews - this is something you don't have in Vite-React sites - you would have to install e.g. Helmet (`npm i helmet`) for this - this is an example of one of the many features frameworks such as Gatsby and Next.js have over and above Vite-React or create-react-app sites - test 404 page - this is also a built-in feature of Gatsby that you would have to set up yourself in a Vite site with React Router, etc. - in your browser, go to: `http://localhost:8000/info` - note that you can click the **Preview custom 404 page** - this is the `src\pages\404.tsx` page - change content and style of the page and see that it shows on the 404 page in the browser ------------------------------------ const pageStyles = { color: "tomato", <p style={{ fontSize:'4rem'}}>404</p> <Link style={{color: 'tomato'}} to="/">Go home</Link>. ------------------------------------ - you then have a page like this:##the404ok - **make new page** - also note that since we ran the **npm run develop** script, we are shown another page first - this page gives us instructions for creating an info page if we want to##tocreatpage - we can simple make a page **src/pages/info.tsx** ------------------------------- import * as React from "react" export default function Component () { return ( <> <h2>Info Page</h2> <p>This is the info page.</p> </> ) } ------------------------------- - refresh the page and you have an info site already:##showtheinfositejij - **set up a link to this page** - note that in the 404 page there is a component named **Link** -------------------------------- import { Link, HeadFC, PageProps } from "gatsby" <Link style={{color: 'tomato'}} to="/">Go home</Link>. -------------------------------- - note that **Link** is imported from **gatsby** not from **react-router-dom** - but it works similarly - update your info page with a Link back to the home page: ------------------------------------------ import * as React from 'react'; import { Link } from "gatsby" export default function Component() { return ( <> <h2>Info Page</h2> <p>This is the info page.</p> <p>Go back to the <Link to="/">home page</Link>.</p> </> ); } ------------------------------------------ - now simplify the home page **src/info.tsx** with a link to the info page ---------------------------------------------- import * as React from 'react'; import { Link } from "gatsby" export default function Component() { return ( <> <h2>My First Gatsby Site</h2> <p>This is the main page.</p> <p>Visit the <Link to="/info">info page</Link>.</p> </> ); } ---------------------------------------------- - you now have a simple two-page site built with Gatsby:#gif#firstgqtgqt - as one discovers these features in frameworks like **Gatsby** and **Next.js**, one realizes how much more they add to React sites out-of-the-box than the site creators **Vite** or **create-react-app**. - **==> STEP 3. Publish npm-Gatsby site to Vercel <==** - push all changes to the two-page site we just created - go to https://vercel.com - **Add new project** - GitHub - Import - (it recognizes Gatsby) - Deploy - takes about 1:20 - site works: https://et010-gatsby-contentful-etc.vercel.app - **==> STEP 4. Installing again with Gatsby CLI <==** - `gatsby -v` gives me this:##thgaver - `npm i -g gatsby-cli` - still the old version##stillold - closed and opened terminal and now has up-to-date version:##openupand - `gatsby new et011-gatsby-basic` - unlike `npm init gatsby` the Gatsby CLI doesn't ask any questions, e.g. doesn't ask to install contentful - `cd et011-gatsby-basic` - `code .` - `gatsby develop` - instead of `npm run develop`, type `gatsby develop` - but this is the same thing because **package.json**: ----------------------------------- "scripts": { "develop": "gatsby develop", ... } ----------------------------------- - the site has a different structure, has multiple pages, etc.##secondgatsb - checking to see that all pages work when published online, e.g. Server Side Rendering - **VERCEL** - pushing to repository - https://github.com/edwardtanguay/et011-gatsby-basic - publishing at https://vercel.com - **Add new project** - GitHub - Import - (it recognizes Gatsby) - Deploy - takes about 1:20 - ask expected, the site works except for **Server Side Rendering** and **Deferred Static Generation**##ssganddontwork - read more here: - [How to properly run gatsby with SSR in a production environment](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/71435583/how-to-properly-run-gatsby-with-ssr-in-a-production-environment) - **NETLIFY** - publishing at https://www.netlify.com - I read that Netlify can handle SSR and DSG pages - new project - search for repository - it detects Gatsby and seems to be installing a plug-in to give Gatsby sites extra functionality:##tejagatrecpg - but it didn't deploy##nonetlify - checking the build logs, it seems to be because Netlify has an incompatible version of Node:##tjenodeagain - this question seems to address this issue by changing the Node version on Netlify - [Netlify says, "error Gatsby requires Node.js 14.15.0 or higher (you have v12.18.0)"—yet I have the newest Node version?](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/70362755/netlify-says-error-gatsby-requires-node-js-14-15-0-or-higher-you-have-v12-18) - **GATSBY CLOUD** - https://www.gatsbyjs.com - sign up and click through, it's very basic like Netlify and Vercel - all defaults - **Build Site** - seems to get an error:##theerrrogacoud - when I click on **view errors** it shows me this:##nologsdok - **Consensus on publishing Gatsby Sites:** - 1. use **Vercel** to publish Gatsby sites without **Server Side Rendering** or **Deferred Static Generation** pages - Gatsby still has quite a bit of advantages without these features, e.g. GraphQL - 2. if you want to get **Server Side Rendering** or **Deferred Static Generation** pages to run on a hosted site - I would recommend doing self-hosting at e.g. Hetzner rather than being tied to a specific solution such as Gatsby Cloud, which doesn't even work with their default start-up site - It seems you set up the server-side rendering with Express and a plugin, see this: - https://github.com/wille/gatsby-plugin-express - **==> STEP 5. Build as much functionality from the CLI-version into the NPM-version <==** - after building in each feature, test online at Vercel - 1. layout and nav bar - 2. Sass - 3. SEO and link-preview optimization - 4. GraphQL data - 5. various data sources - import from JSON - via basic REST API - via Contentful - 6. dynamic images - 7. MDX Markdown

title: Examples of useCallback(), useMemo() and useId()
body:
- useMemo
	- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=THL1OPn72vo
	- does not return the function, it only returns the value of the function
	- caches the result of calling your function
	- see my example: https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=463
- useCallback
	- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_AyFP5s69N4
	- useCallback caches the function itself
	- use it if you want to skip re-rendering of a component if the value of a prop hasn't changed
	- with useCallback, we do not create a new function unless we need to, i.e. unless a specific value changes
	- another scenario in which you would want to use useCallback is if the function you are creating is very slow to create
		- that way you would only create that function only when you need to, not everytime you render
		- but this is rare
	- useCallback uses useMemo internally, like this:
		----------------------------------------
		function useCallback(fn, dependencies) {
			return useMemo(() => fn, dependencies);
		}		
		----------------------------------------		
- useId
	- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_vwCKV7f_eA
	- my howto: https://edwardtanguay.vercel.app/howtos?id=655

title: The 2023 Roadmap for my Datapod project
body:
- My Datapod project is a way for me to **create websites** that I use, which in turn **generate frameworks** which I and others can use to create similar websites. 
	- As I create **new features** to the sites that I use, I regularly generate **a new version of that framework**. 
- In the **past** I built **C#, PHP, Node/Express and React** Datapod frameworks. Starting in **March 2023** I will build **Next.js, Vue.js and Angular** Datapod frameworks:
	- SITE #1: **tech site** - all my web development and technology content
		- site that provides access to all my material concerning technology, web development, programming, e.g. howtos, techitems, forays, tech books, etc.
		- framework: **Next.js**
		- PHASE 1: hosted at Vercel
			- ==> **[tanguay-eu.vercel.app](https://tanguay-eu.vercel.app/about)**
			- development
				- developer can freely edit/add/delete
				- lowdb, no route protection
			- production
				- all users read-only
				- no lowdb access, site reads json files directly 
		- PHASE 2: hosted at Hetzner
			- **tanguay.eu**
			- backend is lowdb
				- local-db.json
					- production: read only
					- local: read/write
				- online-db.json
					- production: read/write
					- local: read only
					- e.g. users (for sign-ups), comments, user-item data such as "notStarted/workingOn/accomplished"
	- SITE #2: **Datapod landing site** - documentation, version/feature information, ticket-system, downloads for Datapod frameworks
		- framework: **Vue.js**
		- PHASE 1: hosted at Vercel
			- ==> **[datapod-tanguay-eu.vercel.app](https://datapod-tanguay-eu.vercel.app/about)**
			- development
				- developer can freely edit/add/delete
				- lowdb, no route protection
			- production
				- all users read-only
				- no lowdb access, site reads json files directly 
		- PHASE 2: hosted at Hetzner
			- **datapod.tanguay.eu**
			- backend is lowdb
				- local-db.json
					- production: read only
					- local: read/write
				- online-db.json
					- production: read/write
					- local: read only
					- e.g. newsletter signups, comments, questions
	- SITE #3: **personal site** - books, languages, fitness, good arguments, blog, anti-echo-chamber
		- framework: **Angular**
		- PHASE 1: hosted at Vercel
			- ==> **[edward-tanguay-eu.vercel.app](https://edward-tanguay-eu.vercel.app/about)**
			- development
				- developer can freely edit/add/delete

- Docker swarm
	- you can use Swarm and Kubernetes together
	- Swarm is a tool from Docker and is enabled by default
	- allows to manage clusters of nodes
		- virtual or physical machiens are nodes
		- in each node you have containers
	- a swarm manager manages the cluster of nodes
	- to create a swarm
		- host machine is manager
		- add virtual machines with Docker to the Swarm
		- initialize a swarm
			- `docker swarm init`
		- now you can add a worker to the swarm##nowaddsdfwsarm
	- single node swarm: one machine
	- multiple-node swarm: multiple machines
	- `docker info`##theswarmsdkfjsanin
	- to see all nodes in swarm
		- `docker node ls`##thewskasjdf
	- add workers
		- `docker stack deploys -c docker-composer.yml`
		- ssh into the machine you wanted to add and then use this command
	- add services to the swarm
		- add node server to swarm
			- `docker service create --replicas 1 --name nodeserver2 node ping docker.com`
	- see all swarm services
		- `docker server ls`
	- choose if you need a tool that is tightly integrated with Docker
- Kubernetes
	- is the standard in the community
	- built by Google
	- much more extensible than swarms
	- can scale to thousands of nodes
	- choose if you want to use an industry standard that is more customizable

title: Get an Astro site up and running
body:
- Astro - built on React - static site builder - lightning-fast, high-performance websites with a modern developer experience - **Astro websites are entirely static, with no JavaScript code whatsoever** - easy to use: Astro's goal is to be accessible to every web developer - Astro vs. Remix - Remix supports server-side rendering - Astro provides a statically-bundled HTML file with minimal to no JavaScript - Astro Islands - reading: https://blog.logrocket.com/understanding-astro-islands-architecture - apparently Astro uses Vite but cannot be set up with `npm create vite` which only shows:##theonlyshvite - you set it up with `npm create astro@latest` - Astro plugin system - first stable releast was August 9, 2022 - key differentiator between Astro and other frameworks - islands architecture - explained here: https://jasonformat.com/islands-architecture - render HTML pages on the server - inject placeholders or slots around highly dynamic regions - these placeholders/slots contain the server-rendered HTML output from their corresponding widget - they denote regions that can then be "hydrated" on the client into small self-contained widgets, reusing their server-rendered initial HTML - similar to progressive enhancement - rendering pages using an islands architecture results in the heavier dynamic portions of the page being initialized not just progressively, but **separately** - individual regions of the page become interactive without anything else on the page needing to be loaded first - each part of the page is an isolated unit, and a performance issue in one unit doesn't affect the others - SSR can actually have a net negative impact on User Experience - sections of that HTML may be missing their client-side interactivity, but the document should at least contain the most essential content - a news page’s HTML would contain the article body, and a product page would contain that product’s description - all of the other content is secondary to this information, and its inclusion in the HTML becomes a product decision - a website that uses standard HTML links for navigation is easier for assistive technologies and web crawlers to use - multiple islands can exist on a page - an island always renders in isolation - each island can use any UI framework or just plain Astro code - Astro generates every website with zero client-side JavaScript by default - every time we render an island on a page, Astro automatically renders it to HTML ahead of time and then strips out all the JavaScript - to use React components in your Astro project, you have to add the @astrojs/react integration into your project - benefit of Astro islands - heavy focus on making your app as light as it can be - every island is loaded in parallel - Astro supports five client directives: - ``: Hydrates the component JavaScript immediately on page load - ``: Hydrates the component JavaScript once the page is done with its initial load - ``: Hydrates the component JavaScript once the component has entered the user’s viewport - ``: Hydrates the component JavaScript once a certain CSS media query is me - ``: Skips HTML server rendering and renders only on the client - demo: https://astro-client-directives-test.netlify.app ----------------------------------------

Welcome to Astro

no directive

No JS, no interactive 

client:load

Loads JS as soon as possible 

client:idle

Loads JS when rendering is over 

client:visible

Loads JS when the button is visible to the user 

client:media

Loads JS when the media query (min-width: 680px) is valid 

client:only

Loads JS only in client (No SSR)

---------------------------------------- - Astro is UI-agnostic - you can use any officially supported UI framework, e.g. - React - Preact - Solid - Svelte - Vue - Lit - you can mix and match different frameworks on the same page - >> watch [VIDEO: Astro Crash Course in 20 Minutes](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zrPVTf761OI) - do tutorial, recommended by Timo: https://astro-tutorial-blog-six.vercel.app - )) work through this article/tutorial: https://blog.logrocket.com/astro-build-faster-apps-less-javascript/ - a longer video [VIDEO: Kevin Powell: Create template layouts for your HTML with Astro SSG](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o7iQAF2EvUU) - questions - how can Astro send zero JavaScript to the browser, doesn't that mean there is no interactivity on the site for the user?

body:
- what I want to do:
	- move my PHP Shared-Hosting-Server website to Hetzner
	- but the email address I've used for decades is also at that domain 
		- I need to host that as well with an IMAP email server or whatever
	- the main thing is that it works 
		- since this email is connected to numerous accounts where I need to receive access codes, etc.
- asking around, got this advice
	- **>>> before you begin, make backup of emails**
		- [OfflineIMAP](https://www.offlineimap.org)
			- downloads your email mailbox(es) as local Maildirs
			- will synchronize both sides via IMAP
			- so this software is used to **synchronize** email accounts
				- which can be also used to **make a backup** of them
			- should run on most platforms supported by Python
				- this repository is for python2 only
				- we do not support Windows
		- [fetchmail](https://www.fetchmail.info)
			- like offlineimap, fetchmail is used to pull emails from a remote mail server and deliver them to a local mailbox or forward them to another email address
				- so this is in effect a **backup**
			- fetchmail supports **IMAP, POP3, ETRN, ODMR, and others**
				- OfflineIMAP supports only IMAP
			- fetchmail doesn't emphasize two-way synchronization as its primary function
				- OfflineIMAP emphasized two-way synchronization
				- for a **backup** this shouldn't be necessary anyway
			- fetchmail is more for simple fetching, backing up
				- OfflineIMAP for keeping mail accounts synchronous
			- if you want to periodically download emails from your email server and store them locally for **backup** purposes, **fetchmail** can be a suitable choice
	- **install an IMAP server**
		- **[DoveCot](https://www.dovecot.org)**
			- works with IMAP and POP3
			- allows users to access their email messages on a server
			- popular for its ability to keep messages on the server and synchronize them across multiple devices
			- supports encryption protocols such as SSL/TLS 
			- supports **mbox** and **maildir** mailbox formats
			- includes support for [Sieve](http://sieve.info), a scripting language that allows users to define mail filtering rules on the server
			- can be [installed with git clone](https://doc.dovecot.org/installation_guide/compiling_source)
			- uses Linux accounts
			- you can set up an SSL certificate with **Let's Encrypt**
			- then you can syrnchronize your IMAP account with **[imapsync](https://imapsync.lamiral.info/doc/TUTORIAL_Unix.html)**
				- open-source command-line tool designed for synchronizing mailboxes between two IMAP servers
		- **[MailCow](https://mailcow.github.io/mailcow-docs)**
			- open-source software suite for hosting email services
			- a comprehensive and user-friendly solution for email hosting, including features such as webmail, calendaring, and contact management
			- often used for creating a full-featured mail server that supports multiple domains and users
			- I read that [mailcow supports Debian 8 (Jessie), Ubuntu LTS 14.04 (Trusty Tahr) and Ubuntu LTS 16.04 (Xenial Xerus)](https://mailcow.github.io/mailcow-docs)
				- I have Debian 11 at Hetzner
		- **[Yunohost](https://yunohost.org)**
			- easily manage a server for your friends, association or enterprise
			- user-friendly interface for managing various services and applications on a server, allowing individuals and small organizations to host their own websites, email services, file storage, and more
			- takes care of Mailserver, Firewall, Domain and connection to apps
			- outside PM2/Nginx it's not recommended
		- **host IMAP-Server as Docker container**
			- for example a [Mailcow Container](https://docs.mailcow.email/i_u_m/i_u_m_install)
- questions
	- why use imapsync with DoveCot, why not e.g. fetchmail?
	- Mailcow supports Debian 8, I have Debian 11, so I can't use it?
	- Yunohost is an operating system?

	- yes, it works, in fact, the browser refreshed after I ran the script
- setting up auto push
	- on my Hetzner machine, added public key content from **id_rsa.pub** to the end of the file **authorized_keys**
	- at GitHub > Repository > Settings > Secrets and Variables > Actions > New Repository Secret##thesecrectss
	- add these three:
		- SERVER_IP = IP Address of Hetzner machine
		- SERVER_USER = username on Hetzner machine
		- SSH_PRIVATE_KEY = Private Key on Hetzner machine (the pair to the public key that is in authorized_keys)##addelikethis
	- creating yaml file:
		- create a workflow:##theactionjss
		- **main.yml**
			----------------------------------------------------
			name: Deploy React App

			on:
			  push:
				branches:
				  - dev

			jobs:
			  build:
				name: Build and Deploy
				runs-on: ubuntu-latest
				steps:
				  - name: Checkout code
					uses: actions/checkout@v3

				  - name: Setup Node.js environment
					uses: actions/setup-node@v3
					with:
					  node-version: "16.18.0"

				  - name: Install SSH key
					uses: webfactory/ssh-agent@v0.5.4
					with:
					  ssh-private-key: ${{ secrets.SSH_PRIVATE_KEY }}

				  - name: Deploy to Server
					run: |
					  ssh -t -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null ${{ secrets.SERVER_USER }}@${{ secrets.SERVER_IP }} <<'EOF'
					  cd /home/edward/projects/ex002-auto-react
					  export PATH=$PATH:/home/edward/.nvm/versions/node/v16.18.0/bin
					  echo $PATH
					  git pull
					  npm install
					  npm run build
					  pm2 reload ex002-auto-react
					  exit
					  EOF			
			----------------------------------------------------
		- notes that YAML files must have spaces, not TABs
